summaries.body: A video shows a chimpanzee named Chacha desperately trying to avoid capture by climbing an electric pole after he fled from a zoo in Japan.

display_asset.caption: Police officers at the site of the shooting of a Houston deputy constable late Wednesday.

summaries.body: A man shot and wounded a deputy constable during a traffic stop in Houston late Wednesday in what the authorities described as an ambush-style attack.

display_asset.caption: A senior citizen learned to use a Facebook account during a class at a branch of the New York Public Library in 2012. Not pictured: the author’s dad.

summaries.body: What do older Americans do on Facebook? The same things as their younger counterparts: Bond with old friends, develop new relationships and keep tabs on loved ones.

display_asset.caption: Opponents of the bill protested outside the Mississippi governor’s mansion last week in Jackson, the capital.

summaries.body: A new law in Mississippi has ignited fierce opposition over its provisions to allow people with religious objections to deny certain services to gay couples.

display_asset.caption: A man walking past a display at a museum in Hong Kong dedicated to remembering the June 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing.

summaries.body: The world's only museum dedicated to China's 1989 Tiananmen protest movement is expected to close this year in Hong Kong.

display_asset.caption: From left, Pedro Almodóvar, director of “Julieta”; Xavier Dolan, director of “It’s Only the End of the World”; and Sean Penn, director of “The Last Face.”
display_asset.credit: From left, Ian Langsdon/European Pressphoto Agency; Guillaume Horcajuelo/European Pressphoto Agency; Ian Langsdon/European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: Movies by Pedro Almodóvar, Xavier Dolan and Sean Penn will compete for the Palme d’Or at this year’s Cannes Film Festival in May.

display_asset.credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Senate voted to ban the import of virtually all ancient artifacts from Syria to discourage looting and trafficking.

display_asset.credit: Joel Philippsen/The Republic, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A man was sentenced to five years in jail for trying to smuggle 51 live turtles from Michigan to Canada inside of his pants.

display_asset.credit: Corey Lowenstein/Raleigh News & Observer, via Getty Images

summaries.body: In response to a law limiting gay and transgender rights, two brewers in North Carolina are cooking up a new beer, Don't Be Mean to People: A Golden Rule Saison.

display_asset.caption: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, left, at a ceremony in January that honored people killed in the 1918 Battle of Kiev. Mr. Poroshenko was impersonated in a conference call with The New York Times editorial board this week.

summaries.body: A man impersonating Ukraine's president called The New York Times. When audio was posted on YouTube, the journalists found themselves in an apparent propaganda war.

display_asset.caption: Harvard has a long tradition of all-male social clubs. The clubs broke official ties with Harvard after it required them to admit women.
display_asset.credit: Charlie Mahoney for The New York Times

summaries.body: Members of the oldest all-male social club at Harvard rejected calls to admit women, saying that doing so would increase the chances of sexual misconduct.

display_asset.caption: Students visited the Richard Rodgers Theater, where a dozen groups of them rapped and sang their responses to the “Hamilton” creator, Lin-Manuel Miranda, before watching a matinee of the show.

summaries.body: New York City students saw "Hamilton" and rapped for Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Broadway show's creator, as part of a program sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation.

display_asset.caption: Matthew Keys, right, with his lawyer, Jason Leiderman, in Sacramento in 2013.

summaries.body: A California journalist, Matthew Keys, was sentenced to two years in federal prison for helping the group Anonymous hack The Los Angeles Times website in 2010.

display_asset.caption: Sonar imaging found the 30-foot movie prop, which sank in 1969.

summaries.body: An underwater drone has found the Loch Ness Monster. Well, it found a model of Nessie that sank during the making of “The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes" in 1969.
A Russian plane flew "dangerously close" to an American ship and a Polish aircraft, the White House said, citing “repeated incidents” over the past year.

display_asset.caption: An image from the teaser trailer for “Doctor Strange.”

summaries.body: In a trailer for "Doctor Strange," Marvel fans get to see a tortured Benedict Cumberbatch, a bald and wizened Tilda Swinton and an Escher-like New York City.

display_asset.caption: Inky the octopus at National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier.

summaries.body: After squeezing through a small gap in his enclosure at the National Aquarium of New Zealand, an octopus named Inky scampered his way to freedom in Hawke's Bay.

display_asset.caption: The Kindle Oasis. Amazon says its Kindle business is still growing, despite competition from other devices.

summaries.body: The new $289 Kindle Oasis e-reader from Amazon has an asymmetrical shape meant to mimic a book, and promises "months and months" of battery life.

display_asset.caption: Wakko, Yakko and their sister, Dot, of “Animaniacs.”

summaries.body: "Animaniacs," a beloved after-school cartoon for children of the '90s, is now on Netflix. It's also going on tour with live performances of many of the show’s songs, including an updated version of "Yakko's World."

display_asset.caption: Alice Paul, second from left, the founder of the National Women’s Party, sewed a 36th star on the flag that flew outside the party’s headquarters in Washington after the 19th Amendment was ratified in 1920. The star represented Tennessee, whose ratification completed the number of states needed to approve the amendment, which gave women the right to vote.

summaries.body: President Obama has designated the Sewall-Belmont House on Capitol Hill as a national monument for women's equality, calling it a symbol of the American fight for civil rights.

display_asset.caption: Two employees of the Drug Enforcement Administration are scheduled to go on trial next month on charges that they lied about ownership in a strip club, shown last May, in New Jersey.
display_asset.credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two D.E.A. employees are trying to bar a lap-dance video from evidence at their trial on charges that during background checks they lied about owning a New Jersey strip club.

display_asset.caption: Macedonians clashed with the police during a protest against President Gjorge Ivanov’s decision to halt a wiretapping inquiry, in Skopje, Macedonia, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: Protesters gathered in Macedonia after the president halted an investigation into widespread corruption in government, including surveillance of up to 20,000 people.

display_asset.caption: Sean Parker is donating $250 million to start the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, an effort that he said represented a new “blueprint for biomedical research funding.”

summaries.body: Sean Parker, the Napster and Facebook pioneer, is donating $250 million for an institute developing ways to unleash patients’ own immune systems to fight cancer.
Arthur Anderson, who performed on radio as a teenager with Orson Welles’s Mercury Theater and was the voice of Lucky Charms cereal’s leprechaun, has died at 93.
A French website that recently posted a recipe for one-pot pasta carbonara set off outrage among Italians over some of the suggested substitutions.

display_asset.caption: Passengers checking in at a Brussels airport in Zaventem last week. Americans and Canadians can generally travel to Europe without a visa, but that may change.

summaries.body: The European Union has delayed until summer a decision on whether to require United States and Canadian citizens to obtain visas to travel to Europe.

display_asset.caption: John Whittingdale in 2015.

summaries.body: John Whittingdale, the British minister of culture, said that he used to date a woman in the sex industry and that tabloids had known about it, but he denied that it had affected his regulation of the news media.

display_asset.caption: Oscar Murillo

summaries.body: When the Colombian artist Oscar Murillo flushed his British passport down an airplane toilet, he had not intended to stage a protest. But the action became one, he said.
Women searching for tech jobs are often setting their salary expectations lower than their male counterparts are, according to Hired, a job marketplace for the industry.
Happy 100th birthday, Beverly Cleary. The Times Book Review looks back at the children's writer and her work, including "Ramona Quimby" and "Henry Huggins."
